book_name: CAE Oxford Human Performance and Limitations

questions.question: With an alveolar partial pressure of oxygen of 55 mm Hg, what is the maximum altitude to breathe 100% oxygen without pressure?
What are the constituents of the atmosphere?
What is the % of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the alveoli at sea level?
On 100% oxygen at 40 000 feet, what height in the atmosphere does the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli equate to?
options: a. The same as at 20000 ft
b. The same as at 10000 ft
c. The same as at 25000 ft
d. The same as at 30000 ft

questions.question: At what height is the partial pressure of oxygen in the lungs approximately half that at sea level?
What is the percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere at 35 000 ft?
What is one of the initial indications of hypoxia?
options: a. Blue tinge in the lips

questions.question: Why does cold make you more susceptible to hypoxia?
options: a. Heart beats faster which uses up more oxygen
b. More energy is required when shivering therefore more oxygen used
c. Lowers temperature of the body which makes it less efficient
d. Lowers temperature of the body and especially the head which has a debilitating effect on the brain

questions.question: What is the first action that should be taken by the pilot in the event of a cabin decompression above 10000 ft?
options: a. Descend as soon as possible
b. Don oxygen mask and check oxygen flow

questions.question: In flight someone complains of feeling alternately hot and cold, anxious, dizzy, tingling at the fingertips and is breathing rapidly. What may they be suffering from?
The carbon dioxide level of the blood level is higher than normal. The brain:
options: a. increases the rate of breathing and pulse rate
b. decreases the rate of breathing and pulse rate
c. increases the pulse rate and decreases rate of breathing
d. decreases the pulse rate and increases rate of breathing

questions.question: What are the times of useful consciousness at 20000 ft (moderate activity):
If the symptoms of hyperventilation occur at an altitude where hypoxia is not a consideration, what is the correct remedial action?
options: b. Decrease rate and depth of breathing
d. If possible lay flat and help to calm sufferer

questions.question: What increases the risk of DCS occurring in flight?
options: a. Scuba diving shortly before flight
b. Snorkel diving shortly before flight

questions.question: What are the restrictions to flying after scuba diving?
options: a. No flying within 48 hours if a depth of 40 ft has been exceeded, otherwise the limit is 12 hours
b. No flying within 48 hours if a depth of 30 ft has been exceeded, otherwise the limit is 24 hours
c. No flying within 12 hours if a depth of 30 ft has been reached, otherwise the limit is 24 hours
d. No flying within 24 hours if a depth of 30 ft has been exceeded, otherwise the limit is 12 hours

questions.question: A pilot has been snorkelling and has exceeded a depth of 30 ft. Are there any restrictions to him/her flying?
options: b. No flying for 12 hours plus 30 minutes for every 10 feet deeper than 30 ft

questions.question: Tidal volume is:
options: a. the volume of air inhaled with each normal breath
b. the volume of air exhaled with each normal breath
c. the volume of air breathed when diving
d. the volume of air inhaled and exhaled with each normal breath

questions.question: The altitude that pressure will be half that of MSL in the standard atmosphere is:
Henry's Law has application in Human Performance to:
options: d. partial pressure in the alveoli

questions.question: Hypoxic hypoxia affects night vision.
Anaemic hypoxia can be:
In commercial aircraft cabin pressure is normally maintained at:
In the event of a passenger showing symptoms of DCS, the aircraft must:
options: c. land as soon as possible

questions.question: The "chokes" are associated with:
Breathing 100% oxygen at 40 000 ft is equivalent of breathing normally at:
What are the times of useful consciousness at 35000 ft (at rest):
